Abstract:
Recent reports indicate that the incidence of peritonitis is relatively high with continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD). Our aim was to determine risk factors for peritonitis in a randomized, controlled CAPSANA study. A total of 848 patients were prospectively randomized in order to receive either high‐volume or standard volume (HD and SD) CAPD. There were no significant differences in the incidence of peritonitis (38 and 42 episodes in the SD and high dialysate volume (HDV) groups, respectively) and mortality (9 and 12%, respectively) after a follow‐up period of 36 months. Of all patient records (n = 3,941), 348 episodes of peritonitis (incidence 79/1,000 catheter‐years) were registered. Independent predictors for peritonitis were type of fluid used (relative risk ratio [RRR] 5.46, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.32‐22.78, P = 0.02) and the use of systemic steroids (hazard ratio [HR] 2.85, 95% CI 1.39‐5.84, P = 0.004). Risk of peritonitis was higher in female gender (HR 1.23, 95% CI 0.98‐1.54, P = 0.09), diabetes (HR 1.16, 95% CI 0.88‐1.54, P = 0.28), older (> or = 50 years) (HR 1.09, 95% CI 0.82‐1.45, P = 0.49) and HDV group. The risk ratio of peritonitis was also higher after the first 1,000 dialysate‐years (RRR 1.40 (CI 1.05‐1.88), P = 0.02).

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The main objective of the study is to test the hypotheses that the combination of a short-term training of the neuromuscular system and the use of rehabilitation techniques will improve the dynamic postural control of persons with a low lumbar degenerative condition.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The protocol of the study was designed following the guidelines to develop clinical trials of the World Health Organization and according to the CONSORT statement. The investigation will be a non-randomized, controlled, parallel-arm clinical trial, that will include two study groups: one that will undergo an intervention program and a second group who will perform the control. The sample of the study will be constituted of 80 patients diagnosed with degenerative disc disease of the lumbar area, from whom 40 participants will go to the intervention or control program. The study will be carried out with a population belonging to the Andalusian health system. It is expected that the intervention program will consist of an initial training of 10 continuous sessions of 60 minutes each, and a second training phase, three months after intervention, in which the subject will repeat a 10-session program similar to the initial one. The intervention program will include three elements: (1) strengthening of the musculature: an orthostatic program of lumbar stabilization exercise, of muscle flexibility and relaxation; and (2) proprioceptive training: a balance training that includes exercises that focus on the visual and proprioceptive sense, with eyes open and vision blocked; and (3) motor learning: practice of motor sequences, whose complexity will increase progressively, in order to simulate the movements of daily life. The control group will carry out only motor learning with progressively complex movements similar to those of daily life. The sessions of training in both groups will be individualized. The training program will be held in a physiotherapy room prepared for the training sessions. The program is expected to finish in six months. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Cognitive changes, depression and anxiety are very evident during stroke and recovery periods. They can increase mortality and morbidity of stroke. Many of them can be related to cerebral infarction which may be treated by thrombolysis. So, the purpose of this study was to determine whether there is a significant change in the clinical characteristics of stroke patients after thrombolysis. The data collection will continue over a period of 3 months (Jul - Nov). The researchers will record the severity of cognitive symptoms of patients receiving thrombolysis, the duration of time they are in the hospital, and the changes in the psychological wellbeing of patients during their stay at the hospital. In the case of patient death, the family will be asked to complete our questionnaire. The clinical scores of the patients before and after thrombolysis will be compared. According to research by Lee and others in Taiwan in 2009, anxiety symptoms of patients after thrombolysis were lower compared to symptom severity prior to treatment. Also, in a study by Kroenke et al in 1998, 1 in 6 people between the ages of 18 and 65 in the United States was depressed or had depression symptoms.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Stroke is a major cause of health care costs and medical disability, so the number of studies is increasing rapidly. In contrast to acute neurological symptoms such as acute motor paralysis in stroke survivors, most patients have sequelae from cognitive impairment and mood-related symptoms in particular. Therefore, there is a need to assess cognitive symptoms, mood and emotional changes of patients to improve their quality of life. Thrombolytic therapy should be carried out in the emergency room, but it is not commonly administered due to a lack of awareness or poor compliance. The purpose of this study was to determine the effects of thrombolysis on the clinical characteristics of stroke patients. In the case of death, the family will be asked to complete our questionnaire. The clinical characteristics of patients before and after thrombolysis and the factors affecting the clinical characteristics were also explored. The data collection will be performed by a trained nurse on admission and discharge.

Abstract:
Background/Aim: The aim of the work is to evaluate the ability of the NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) to predict the complications of the subacute acute ischemic stroke and the rate of favorable outcome. Methods: A prospective study was conducted at a University Hospital over a 24 months period. The study population included the subacute and acute stroke patients, according to the guidelines of the American Heart Association and American Stroke Association, which were admitted from January 2018 to December 2019. These criteria included the age 18 to 85 years and the absence of a history of stroke. The NIHSS was done at admission. Also, the patient history and examination findings were recorded. The patients’ files were reviewed 3 months after discharge to see what are the most common medical complications and the rate of favorable outcome. Result: The study included 107 patients, the first two months of observation are the acute stages, and the next 10 months are the subacute stages. It showed a great number of medical complications, including pneumonia (56%), urinary tract infection (34.4%), sepsis (25.2%) followed by cerebral edema (1.8%) and upper gastrointestinal bleeding (1.8%) as the worst complication. Pneumonia and urinary tract infection represent (80.8%), a great percentage of total complications. The total number of favorable outcomes for the acute patients is 55%, and the ones for the subacute patients is 31%. The NIHSS score significantly correlates to the most common medical complications and the favorable outcome. Conclusion: Acute stroke is the most common neurological emergency. The NIHSS score correlates to medical complications and the percentage of a good outcome. It is a strong tool for stratifying the severity of stroke.

Study comparing the association between spinal manipulative therapy and exercise and the effect on balance and proprioception after stroke

Abstract:
Objective: This study aimed to compare the effects of exercise and spinal manipulative therapy (MANIP) and exercise/Manip on balance and postural stabilization as well as postural control and proprioception of individuals suffering from stroke. Background Data: After a stroke, patients often suffer from mobility disorders such as poor posture and reduced postural stability. The goal of our study is to find out if there is a difference between exercise and manipulation in improving the stability and posture of individuals suffering from a stroke. Methods: This research is a randomized controlled trial with two parallel groups. The trial participants are patients between the ages of 18 and 75 who have had a stroke at least six months ago, can walk without assistance for at least 10 meters, and have a minimum score of 15 on the Mini‐Mental Status Test. Each individual will be randomly assigned to either the control group or either the exercise group or the exercise/Manip group, depending on a randomization schedule. The exercise group will undergo an intervention consisting of stretching, strengthening, and functional exercises. The exercise and Manip group will undergo an intervention consisting of stretching, strengthening, functional and Manip exercises. Both groups will receive therapy for a total of 12 treatments (60 minutes each). The outcome measures will be assessed before (T0) and after (T1) treatment. The assessment tools include the Berg Balance Scale, Dynamic Gait Index (DGI), The Timed Up and Go Test, the 6‐minute walking test, and the 10‐meter walking velocity test. The following outcomes will be analyzed: postural stability, balance control, postural control, proprioception, balance of the center of gravity on the supporting surface, and velocity, distance covered, and the number of contacts between the upper and lower extremities. Results: This study is still in progress. Results will be reported as median and range (or mean ± standard deviation if normally distributed) for quantitative data. For qualitative data, the number and percentage of participants will be presented. Statistical significance will be defined as a p‐value of less than 0

PPI-induced subclinical hypovitaminosis is not associated with fracture risk in men aged 50-69 years

Abstract:
INTRODUCTION: The hypothesis of a potential effect of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) on vitamin D metabolism has been postulated. However, it is still a matter of debate as to whether such a mechanism exists and if it affects clinical outcomes. AIM: Evaluate the potential association between vitamin D status and PPI use with fracture occurrence in elderly men from the Prevention with FeO and tRobolx IbUPROfen Effectiveness (PREFORMA) trial. METHODS: An ancillary substudy from the randomised controlled PREFORMA trial was performed in a subset of male participants (n = 346) aged 50‐69 years enrolled in primary care. 25‐hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) serum levels were measured at baseline and fractures were self‐reported at one year of follow‐up.RESULTS: Baseline vitamin D levels were normal in most men (97.7%); mean (SD) serum vitamin D was 66.2 ± 20.9 nmol/L in men who used PPI (n = 100) and 69.7 ± 24.8 nmol/L in men who did not (n = 250). Fractures (n = 25) occurred in both PPI users and non‐users in a comparable manner (RR = 0.90; 95% CI 0.48‐1.70). Low vitamin D status at baseline was not associated with increased risk of fracture (RR = 0.83; 95% CI 0.40‐1.73).CONCLUSION: Vitamin D levels were not associated with fracture occurrence, irrespective of PPI use. These findings refute the hypothesis of a potential mechanistic link between PPI use and vitamin D‐mediated fracture risk in elderly men.

Research suggests VTCE helps decrease opioid use in those managing chronic pain. In addition, practicing tai chi has been shown to decrease anxiety. The VTCE program focuses on 4 main movements that are designed to focus inward, so the benefits of tai chi are achieved in a short time. VTCE is designed to be accessible from any location with an internet connection and can be practiced from the comfort of one’s environment at home. We believe the low cost and potential efficacy of this intervention for reducing opioid dose in the general population suggest that it would be beneficial for people experiencing opioid use disorder. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of this randomized controlled trial is to test the effectiveness of a novel digital video feedback intervention that incorporates 3D imaging technology to deliver virtual rehabilitation. This study uses novel digital technology and an individualized assessment of movement disorder characteristics to deliver customized intervention in two forms: Virtual Rehabilitation and Non-Virtual Physical Exercise. The project is focused on patients with essential tremor, which is a disabling tremor that can affect both upper and lower limbs.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Essential tremor is a common neurological condition that is the most prevalent movement disorder and the primary cause of postural/intention tremor, which affects approximately 6 million individuals worldwide. The pathophysiology of essential tremor is not fully understood, however, it is believed to involve brain regions involved in controlling movement. While many conventional medicines are available to reduce the severity of tremor, these medicines work only in about one-third of people with the condition. In order to improve the outcome after medication, various physical rehabilitation strategies have been investigated, but they have all shown limited success.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this prospective, randomized, noninferiority, multicenter, adaptive design study is to determine whether a 120-mg dose of moxifloxacin is noninferior to the standard of care (400 mg) used to treat acute bacterial pneumonia (ABP) in adults.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This clinical study plans to enroll 360 subjects in the United States and to randomize them equally to a short or long course treatment of moxifloxacin 120 mg or 400 mg once daily for 3, 5, or 7 days. The study will be conducted in two phases: screening and acute treatment. The primary hypothesis is that a moxifloxacin 120-mg dose is not inferior to the 400-mg dose for short course treatment, and equivalent or nearly equivalent for long course treatment of ABP.

Interventional Model Description: We chose a single arm, single stage interventional study design with a planned cross-sectional and observational phase. This design allows for us to estimate the baseline uptake of germline testing in black patients with high-risk prostate cancer. In our proposed study, all consecutive black patients with high-risk PCa who meet NCCN guideline recommendations to undergo genetic testing will be offered participation in the study. All subjects will also receive the intervention, a behavioral educational toolkit comprising a video on germline genetic testing and a print pamphlet that provides an overview of the benefits of genetic testing, the difference between germline testing and somatic testing, and potential results and implications. The behavioral educational toolkit is designed to educate the patients on germline testing uptake. The planned cross-sectional and observational phase of the study will enrich our understanding of the current landscape of germline testing and will allow us to monitor the impact of the intervention on the germline genetic testing uptake rate within our organization.

Abstract:
Thirty to 40% of all lung cancers are peripheral, with a majority arising in the lower lobes. When diagnosed early, peripheral stage I non‐small cell lung cancers (NSCLC) have excellent long‐term survival after resection. Although surgical resection offers a curative approach in many patients, it is invasive and potentially morbid. Minimally invasive strategies such as robotic‐assisted bronchoscopic (RAB) laser ablation (LABA) of NSCLC lesions have been developed to reduce morbidity while achieving complete tumor ablation. However, the recurrence rates for minimally invasive ablation are higher than for surgery. Herein we report the results of a phase 1 clinical trial using Padeliporfin, a second‐generation photosensitizer with good uptake in solid tumors. After successful robotic access of peripheral lung lesions, intra‐tumoral injection of PadDelPorfin, followed by IV injection of PadDelPorfin and subsequent intraluminal laser ablation, 5 of 6 patients undergoing Padeliporfin vascular targeted photodynamic (VTP) ablation were disease‐free 10 months after treatment, with a single recurrence outside the ablated volume successfully treated. This promising approach for treatment of stage I peripheral NSCLC provides a high probability of local control while potentially sparing patients the morbidity and mortality of surgery.

Abstracts

PURPOSE/BACKGROUND: To assess the efficacy of using a novel image stabiliser (iSorb, OCULUS) for image‐guided scleral buckling to reduce the operating time.METHOD: The time taken for vitreoretinal surgeons (VRS) to complete a scleral buckling procedure was recorded during pre‐ and post‐training using a novel image stabiliser. The operating time between using a conventional bimanual operating method and using the novel image stabiliser was recorded at different stages of the procedure. Twenty‐five VRS were randomly allocated to each group. The operating time for each stage of the scleral buckling procedure was calculated as a percentage of the total procedure time.RESULTS: The mean operating time was shorter in the image stabiliser group at each stage of the scleral buckling procedure (P=0.015). There was no learning effect on operating time for the VRS in the bimanual operating method group (P=0.451). However, there was a significant reduction in operating time from the beginning to the end of the procedure for the VRS in the image stabiliser group (r=‐0.991, P=0.039).CONCLUSIONS: Use of the novel image stabiliser (iSorb, OCULUS) enables a reduction in surgery time, especially at the beginning of the procedure, compared to a conventional bimanual operating method.

Brief Summary

The aim of the study is to assess the effectiveness of the MIG-E treatment in terms of pain relief and quality of life improvement. It represents also an exploratory study, to evaluate any possible renal and bone injury during treatment.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Lithotripsy with Electromagnetic Energy (MEE) has been used for the last 25 years as a successful technology to treat stones and treat patients. The MEE system is a non invasive technique that works by means of extracorporeal and closed loop shock waves. MEE has been used for 20 years as a procedure to resolve kidney stones that cannot be extracted by other methods. It has more advantages compared to previous techniques. Firstly, it improves pain management; Secondly it has fewer complications; Thirdly it reduces the risk of new infections. MEE is also effective for the dissolution of ureteral stones. Nevertheless it has also been successfully applied to treat other pathologies: cysts of epididymis, testis and penis, stones in the prostate, etc. Nowadays, MEE for stones has evolved, and the procedure has also been used to treat patients with neuropathies. The aim of the study is to assess the effectiveness of the MIG-E treatment in terms of pain relief and quality of life improvement.

Background: The current guidelines recommend yearly CT‐scan examination of aortic stent‐grafts to detect graft‐migration and other complications. These examinations are time‐consuming and expose the patient to increased radiation dose. A non‐invasive device that allows reliable estimation of aneurysmal volume and graft migration without irradiation might contribute to decreasing surveillance protocols and could improve cost‐effectiveness. Purpose: To compare semi‐automated analysis by anatomical landmarks with a dedicated fully automated software in 400 infra‐renal aortic stent‐grafts over a 5‐year period versus a simple circumference measurement in 200 aortic stent‐grafts, to measure stent‐graft migration, to determine the feasibility and interobserver reproducibility. Methods: One hundred patients with an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm treated with an endovascular aortic repair in the past year were selected: Fifty of them with a dedicated fully automated analysis using a software that detects geometric landmarks of the stent‐graft (Vessel Navi; Volumetric S.r.l., Rome, Italy). For the other 50 patients we performed an external‐vessel reconstruction by an orthogonal segmentation without automatic detection of vascular wall and lumen contours (Medipix, Milano, Italy). A dedicated software (EVE) superimposes previous images and calculates the volume difference. Results: Analysis of both datasets was realized by an expert surgeon and a senior radiologist. In 18.5% our algorithm failed to detect the aneurysm and we had to resort to the segmentation, and in 21% of cases, the landmarks of the stent‐grafts were lost for both methods. Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background and Scientific Rationale Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) is a life-threatening respiratory condition characterized by repetitive partial or complete airway obstruction that occurs during sleep and has serious implications for human health. Currently, OSA is the world's fastest-growing chronic disease but is understudied and underdiagnosed. It is estimated that up to 25% of adults over 30 years of age are affected worldwide. OSA often leads to impaired daytime functioning and impaired cognition. It is responsible for the increased risk of car accidents and is associated with obesity, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, cognitive impairment and stroke. Studies have shown that about 85% of people with OSA have obesity, which further exacerbates the condition. Obstructive sleep apnea is also associated with an increased risk of death. Current treatment options for OSA include lifestyle changes such as weight loss, the use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) devices, surgery to remove obstructions in the upper airway, and lifestyle interventions to prevent weight gain and obesity. However, adherence to these treatments is often low, and there is a need for more effective treatment options. Emerging technology and research have shown that transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) has the potential to improve cognitive functioning and symptoms in individuals with OSA. tDCS is a form of neurostimulation that involves delivering a low-level electrical current to the brain to modulate brain activity and improve cognitive functioning. Previous studies have shown that tDCS improves cognitive functioning in individuals with mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease, and stroke. In individuals with OSA, tDCS has been shown to improve measures of alertness, sleepiness, and cognitive functioning. However, there is a lack of evidence regarding the effectiveness of tDCS in the treatment of OSA. Objectives The primary objective of this study is to determine the effectiveness of cognitive rehabilitation training (CRT) and tDCS as a treatment option for Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA). Specifically, the study will examine the changes in cognitive functioning, quality of life, daytime sleepiness, and adherence to treatment,

Brief Summary
-----------------
Treatment for advanced ovarian cancer involves both chemotherapy and cytoreductive surgery. One challenge of treatment is that it is often difficult to measure the effectiveness of each treatment modality. In this study, the investigators are using blood and tissue samples to learn more about the biology of patient responses to treatments. The goal of the investigators' study is to understand how the immune system plays a role in the success or failure of these treatments.

-----------------
This study will recruit 50 women from across the United States and Europe who have newly diagnosed Stage III or IV Ovarian Cancer. The purpose of the study is to investigate, as the main objective, whether the effect of spinal flexion exercise therapy can be improved by correcting the pelvis (pelvic distraction) and if this is the case for how long and how well.

To compare the change in spine angle between both groups.

3. Experimental: 150 min/wk aerobic exercise
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants who will engage in aerobic exercise for 150 minutes per week.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention will involve moderate- to vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise.

4. Experimental: 225 min/wk aerobic exercise
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants who will engage in aerobic exercise for 225 minutes per week.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention will involve moderate- to vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise.
   - Reasoning: This arm is designed to test the effects of a high dose of aerobic exercise on chemotherapy relative dose intensity. By including a higher dose arm, researchers can assess whether increasing the duration of exercise further improves outcomes compared to the lower dose arms.

5. Experimental: 300 min/wk aerobic exercise
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants who will engage in aerobic exercise for 300 minutes per week.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention will involve moderate- to vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise.
   - Reasoning: This arm is included to evaluate the effects of a very high dose of aerobic exercise on chemotherapy relative dose intensity. By comparing this arm to the other dose arms, researchers can determine if there is a ceiling effect or if higher doses of exercise continue to provide additional benefits.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, single-center, double blind study that seeks to compare the local effects of dupilumab and placebo against HDM allergen challenge among uncontrolled asthmatic patients. Primary outcome is the change of blood and skin basophils count, blood and skin eosinophils, and allergen-induced cytokine responses following the 20-minute allergen challenge in response to house dust mite.

Detailed Description
-----------------
A randomized, placebo-controlled, single-center, double-blind study to assess the allergen-induced inflammatory response of patients with mild and moderate asthma using skin biopsy and aeroallergen challenge test. The study will involve 60 adults, 18 years of age or older, who meet all the inclusion criteria, have mild and moderate asthma, and whose Asthma Control Test Score (ACT-5) ≤ 20 points. Subjects with a previous diagnosis of atopic dermatitis will be excluded if the disease is active at the time of enrollment or if the treatment is ongoing. In this trial, patients in study group will be given an intravenous injection of dupilumab 300 mg every 2 weeks for 12 weeks. Patients in the placebo group will be given placebo at the same dose at the same time period. The aeroallergen challenge test will be carried out 10 minutes prior to intravenous administration of dupilumab/placebo and 5, 15, 25, 45 minutes after the intravenous administration of dupilumab/ placebo. In addition, skin biopsy will be used to compare the difference in interleukin IL 4, IL 13 and IL 5 between the placebo group and the study group at five time points: Baseline, 5, 15, 25, 45 minutes.

Official Title

Dupilumab Effects Against Aeroallergen Challenge (DUPAC)

Abstract:
Background and Purpose: In response to increasing recognition of the importance of the intestinal microbiome in health and disease, human gut microbiota transplantation trials are increasingly being used to study human microbiome in health and disease. This study utilized prebiotic fibre, inulin, as a form of gut microbiota transplantation to investigate the effect of microbiome manipulation in chronic inflammatory disease. It aimed to identify microbiome signatures following gut microbiota transplantation, to examine whether such signatures affect disease outcomes, and to assess the effects of gut microbiota transplantation in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Methods: Twelve patients with active disease (disease activity score (DAS28) >3.2) participated in a single centre randomised controlled trial. After a washout period, participants consumed one of two supplements for four weeks: inulin or a placebo. Faecal samples were collected at baseline, four weeks and at 12 weeks. The DAS28 score was assessed at week zero and 12. An intestinal microbiome was profiled by next‐generation sequencing using 16S ribosomal RNA (rRNA) gene sequencing, and the data were statistically analysed. The impact of the transplanted microbial signatures on RA disease activity was determined using a probabilistic Bayesian approach. Results: There was a significant decrease in DAS28 at 12 weeks compared with baseline. The baseline gut microbiome composition of two patients who achieved remission differed from those patients who did not; one patient had an increased abundance of Enterococcacea family while another had a greater abundance of Akkermansia muciniphila. No differences in the gut microbiome composition at the end of four and 12 weeks were seen in those patients who achieved clinical improvement or not. Conclusion: Although the overall population demonstrated a trend towards clinical improvement, this change was not associated with a detectable change in the gut microbiome. Further investigation of the role of selected commensals in rheumatoid arthritis is warranted.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is an innovative clinical trial that tests the effects of diet, exercise, and other lifestyle factors on depression and metabolic syndrome by measuring the effects on molecular phenotypes (proteins) and metabolites. Patients will be randomized to one of two different lifestyle interventions for 12 weeks and then will return to usual care for another 6 months.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Levels of the HEXB2 gene's product (FBP-26) are associated with major depressive disorder/unipolar depression (MDD/ UD) and also with metabolic syndrome (MetS). MetS is a cluster of disorders associated with both MDD and UD and involves high blood pressure, high and bad cholesterol, obesity, and insulin resistance. FBP-26 causes insulin resistance by inhibiting phosphofructokinase, one of the key enzymes involved in the metabolism of sugar into energy. We theorize that lowering FBP-26 concentrations with changes in lifestyle can improve the blood sugar-insulin system and potentially alleviate the negative effects of MetS. This randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial will allow us to test for the first time the hypothesis that reduced FBP-26 levels due to a program of lifestyle changes improves blood sugar levels, weight, fat distribution, and depression in subjects at risk for MetS. MetS is increasingly recognized as a leading cause of depression in older adults and causes morbidity and mortality. The trial is a randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel-group clinical trial of a diet and exercise intervention. This trial will enroll two groups of subjects with MetS: one high and one low in FBP-26 concentrations. All subjects will be treated with a placebo for twelve weeks and then usual medical

This study aims to quantify the prevalence of hepatitis C virus (HCV)‐associated histopathology (HPH) in cirrhotic patients with HCV viremia and to determine factors affecting HPH development. Forty biopsy‐proven chronic, HCV (HCV) antibody‐positive, HCV RNA‐positive patients who received standard‐of‐care therapy between February 1993 and February 1996 were included. Fifty‐one biopsy‐proven patients who received HCV treatment between November 2003 and October 2005 with or without concurrent anticirrhotic therapy were prospectively enrolled. Patients were followed up until December 31, 2006. The prevalence of HPH was higher in patients treated before 2000 (63.6%) than it was in patients treated after 2000 (25%; P = 0.0001). The development of HPH decreased with the introduction of peginterferon alfa‐2a alone (25%) and therapy with peginterferon alfa‐2a plus ribavirin (10%; P = 0.0008). HCV treatment with boceprevir‐containing triple therapy was also associated with decreased HPH development but was not significant (13%; P = 0.7). The HPH development rate was lower in patients with baseline alanine aminotransferase ≤5 times the upper limit of normal (UUN) (20%) than in those with liver dysfunction (HPH prevalence 83.3%; P < 0.0001). However, the presence of liver dysfunction at the time of treatment initiation was not associated with HPH development (P = 0.83). Thank you for that information. Now, let's focus on the study arms. Based on the details you've provided, we can design four study arms. The first arm will be the active comparator for the adaptive phenotypes, where participants will receive the study drug. The second arm will be the experimental group for the maladaptive phenotypes, also receiving the study drug. The third arm will be the placebo comparator for the adaptive phenotypes, and the fourth arm will be the placebo comparator for the maladaptive phenotypes. Does this sound good to you?

Certainly! Let's start with the active comparator for the adaptive phenotypes. This group will consist of the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups. Participants will be administered Dupilumab (Dupixent), an interleukin-4 receptor alpha antagonist. They will also be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The goal is to evaluate the efficacy of Dupilumab in individuals with adaptive phenotypes.

The experimental group for maladaptive phenotypes will also be divided into Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. Participants in this group will receive Dupilumab (Dupixent) and undergo exposure to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The purpose is to assess the effectiveness of Dupilumab in individuals with maladaptive phenotypes and compare the treatment response between adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes.

The placebo comparator arms will mirror the adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes. Participants in the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups will receive an inert placebo instead of the active drug but will still be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The same applies to the Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. These arms are important for establishing a baseline response in adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes when not receiving the active drug.

You want to know whether the implantable ECG holter device is effective in detecting atrial fibrillation episodes and reducing recurrence. Also, you want to compare patient outcomes between the experimental arm and the standard care arm. Based on this, we suggest the following primary and secondary objectives for your study:

Primary Objective: To determine the recurrence rate of atrial fibrillation in patients post-ICU discharge with an implantable ECG holter device (in experimental arm) and standard care (in control arm) within 2 years.

Secondary Objectives:
1. To compare the cardiac events such as arrhythmia (atrial fibrillation/flutter, atrial tachycardia, sustained or nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, other arrhythmias) between the experimental arm and standard care arm.
2. To compare the number of hospitalizations and duration of hospital stays between the experimental arm and standard care arm.
3. To compare the mortality rate between the experimental arm and standard care arm.
4. To compare the quality of life (measured using the EuroQol 5-Dimension 5-Level (EQ-5D-5L) questionnaire) between the experimental arm and standard care arm.

We will use the following statistical methods to achieve the study objectives:
1. For the primary objective, we will calculate the recurrence rate of atrial fibrillation in both study arms using descriptive statistics such as number and percentage. We will then use the chi-square test or Fisher's exact test to compare the recurrence rate between the experimental arm and standard care arm.
2. For the secondary objectives, we will use appropriate statistical tests such as t-tests, chi-square tests, or log-rank tests, as appropriate, to compare the cardiac events, hospitalizations, mortality rate, and quality of life between the two study arms.

Please keep in mind that this is just a general outline of the study design and statistical analysis methods. The choice of statistical methods may change based on the data collected during the study. Abstract:
Background: To investigate the effects of low-dose inosine on the cognitive test battery in 16–65 years schizophrenia patients with poor medication adherence in the real‐world setting. Methods: Open randomised, active‐control, parallel‐group phase II trial on 23 inpatient/outpatient schizophrenia patients with poor medication adherence who used 1‐2 antipsychotic drugs. Patients were randomly (1:1 ratio) assigned to receive add‐on inosine 0.5 g twice a day or lorazepam 2–4 mg twice a day for 20 consecutive days. The primary outcome was the improvement of the MATRICS Concentration Index (MCI). Other cognitive tests were also assessed. Results: Mean changes of MCI from baseline to endpoint values were significantly smaller in the inosine group than in the lorazepam group. The response rates were 31% in the inosine group versus 13% in the lorazepam group. Both groups had similar improvement of positive and negative symptoms scores and no serious or serious adverse events. Conclusions: Inosine is a promising add‐on treatment for schizophrenia symptoms. It can also improve the cognitive function and the quality of life of these patients. ©

Study comparing multiple arms
=================
Studies with multiple study arms provide flexibility in study design. They can be used to investigate the effect of different doses of a drug, different durations of treatment, or the combination of different treatments.

They can also be used to compare the effects of different types of drugs in different groups of patients.
In this case, multiple study arms are used to compare the effects of multiple doses of Amlitelimab in patients with moderate-to-severe AD who have had an inadequate response to prior biologic or oral JAK inhibitor therapy.
This is done by including three study arms in the trial: two of them are the Experimental arms, which receive Amlitelimab dose 1 or 2, respectively, in addition to topical corticosteroids and topical tacrolimus or pimecrolimus. The third study arm, the Placebo Comparator arm, includes a comparison group that receives a placebo injection along with topical corticosteroids and topical tacrolimus or pimecrolimus.
By comparing the efficacy and safety outcomes between these different arms, the study can determine the optimal dose of Amlitelimab, as well as evaluate the efficacy and safety of Amlitelimab when administered in combination with topical treatments.

The different study arms enable researchers to assess the effects of treatments separately and in combination, providing a more comprehensive understanding of the drug's therapeutic potential.

The advantages of using multiple study arms in a trial include:
- Increased flexibility and versatility in study design, allowing for examination of different doses and treatments.
- A more comprehensive understanding of the drug's efficacy and safety profile, as different treatment arms can provide different insights into the drug's therapeutic potential.
- Increased ability to examine the drug's effectiveness in a range of patient populations and clinical settings.

However, there are also challenges that may arise from multiple study arms, including:
- Increased complexity of trial design and administration, which may increase the costs and time commitment associated with the study.

Abstract:
Background and Aims. Fibromyalgia is a complex syndrome that affects women more often than men. Previous studies showed that physical interventions such as aerobic or resistance training have no positive effect on fibromyalgia symptoms. We hypothesized that combined aerobic and strength training are feasible and effective in women with fibromyalgia. The aim of this study was to assess the effect of 12‐weeks of combined aerobic and strenght training in patients with fibromyalgia. Material and Methods. The study included 30 women with fibromyalgia, aged from 18 to 55 years. The participants performed 40‐minute training 2 times a week during 4 months. An aerobic session consisted of moderate‐intensity treadmill walking, elliptical training, or stationary bicycling, while a strength‐training session consisted of exercises performed on aerobics and step platforms, resistance bands, and free weight. Before and after the sessions, participants' perception of pain, health‐related quality of life, depressive symptoms, and physical abilities were evaluated. The pre and post‐sessions were compared using the unpaired t test. Results. We found significant improvement in the overall score of visual analog scale for pain and overall health scale score of Short‐Form 36, and significant reduction in the scores of Beck Depression Inventory‐II in the group of women with fibromyalgia following the sessions. Conclusion. Combined aerobic and resistance training improved women's perception of pain and mood and overall well‐being. Further research is indicated to verify the effects of this type of combined training program on symptoms of fibromyalgia among women.

The overall purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of Advance Care Planning (ACP) on the psychosocial wellbeing of formerly homeless older adults receiving Permanent Supportive Housing (PSH). This randomized clinical trial will be conducted with formerly homeless older adults, ages 55 and older, who have been in PSH for a minimum of three months, are able to provide informed consent, and are not planning to move out of the housing program. The specific objective of this study is to determine the extent to which ACP reduces older adults' psychological distress and improves other aspects of their physical and psychosocial wellbeing. This study aims to examine the effects of ACP on previously homeless adults within the homeless service domain and beyond. The study uses a quasi-experimental design with two arms: 1) facilitated group ACP and 2) facilitated one-on-one ACP. Older adults will complete psychosocial measures before, immediately after, and at 6 and 12-month intervals following ACP. The study aims to establish whether psychosocial wellbeing has improved as a result of ACP. The findings will help in redesigning current healthcare systems and inform practices that benefit all populations of homeless older adults..

The screening process for depression that takes place in psychiatric hospitals and outpatient clinics is time-consuming and relies on self-reporting by the patient, which may lead to a false diagnosis. If these problems can be overcome, it might lead to more timely and accurate treatment of mental health illnesses that require prompt attention to avoid complications.To address this concern, we developed the Rapid Mood Screener (RMS), a practical method to aid healthcare providers in diagnosing mental illnesses, including major depressive disorder, bipolar 1 depression, and schizophrenia through a single set of questions. We hypothesize that the RMS will be more accurate in diagnosing depression and other mental health illnesses than self-reporting by the patient.The application of the RMS can help healthcare providers quickly diagnose and accurately assess individuals with depression, bipolar depression, and schizophrenia using a set of easy-to-use questions. However, HSCT is not a cure and life-long medication is required after HSCT. HSCT for children with these transfusion-dependent conditions allows these children to lead a transfusion-free life. HSCT can also improve the heart function and survival of patients suffering from end-stage cardiac iron overload

Detailed Description
-----------------
Thalassemia major (TM) is an inherited lifelong condition that results from the reduction or absence of hemoglobin synthesis. Approximately 30% of the patients with thalassemia major are from the Mediterranean region including Egypt, Syria, North Greece, Southern Italy, Cyprus, Turkey, and Jordan. Balkans, Iraqi, Iranian, and Arab countries. Despite significant advances in medical management, TM remains a life-long debilitating illness. The only curative treatment for thalassemia major is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). The outcomes of HSCT in patients with thalassemia major were better in the recent years due to improved supportive care and advances in immune suppression management. HSCT for children with TM allows these children to lead a transfusion-free life and they have a good possibility of a normal life after HSCT. HSCT can also improve the heart function and survival of patients suffering from end-stage cardiac iron overload.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Hyaluronan competes with chondroitin sulfate for the same surface receptors. The binding of hyaluronan by CD44 inhibits the interaction with perlecan and chondroitin sulfate and prevents the binding of tumor inhibitory factors and cytokines. CD44 is overexpressed in many solid tumor types so that it is of interest that the expression of hyaluronan is significantly increased in advanced cancers with CD44 expression. By sequestering hyaluronan, CD44 can prevent anti-tumor immune responses. Preclinical studies have shown that the blockage of CD44 and hyaluronan binding or the use of hyaluronan-neutralizing antibodies can unmask perlecan and enhance tumor inhibition and immune responses to improve overall clinical outcomes.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Study Objective: The objective of this study is to assess the preliminary activity of BIIB013 in patients with advanced solid tumors. Primary Objective: Determine the maximum tolerated dose of BIIB013 (0.42 mg/kg intravenously over 30 min every 14 days in the absence of unacceptable toxicity). Secondary Objectives: Assess the safety, pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of BIIB013 in these tumor types. Evaluate efficacy signals at the maximum tolerated dose. Exploratory Biomarkers: To assess for changes in levels of circulating immune biomarkers, immune cell frequencies and immune cell functional activity in patient populations who receive BIIB013. To assess for changes in levels of plasma and/or urine VEGF-A proteolytic fragments, tumor-associated circulating DNA and immune cells in patient populations who receive BIIB013. Eligibility Criteria: Patients must have histologically or cytologically confirmed solid tumor and must be documented to have disease that is recurrent, relapsed, progressive, metastatic or unresectable. After cerebral hemorrhage, the mortality rate is extremely high, and even for survivors, the degree of neurological deficit or disability is significant. Statins have been shown to reduce mortality and improve neurological deficits after stroke. There is concern that if a large amount of atorvastatin is used simultaneously with a large dose of rosuvastatin, the risk of myotoxicity due to an increase in serum statin levels will increase, and therefore, it is necessary to observe whether the combination of rosuvastatin and atorvastatin is more beneficial for patients with cerebral hemorrhage. The purpose of this study is to see if the combination of atorvastatin and rosuvastatin is more beneficial for patients with cerebral hemorrhage.

Brief Summary
-----------------
This study will determine if a drug-eluting bone cement (Palmoris) can increase the amount of bone density and minimize pain and swelling after a knee surgery to repair a broken thighbone.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Total hip arthroplasty (THA) is currently the standard surgical procedure in the treatment of femoral neck fracture in older adults. Unfortunately, THA often results in painful and disabling joint problems after surgery. A promising therapy involves direct injection of the defect site with a biocompatible drug-eluting bone cement (Palmoris). The drug eluting bone cement Palmoris contains the anti-inflammatory drug ketoprofen. Studies in the United States have shown that Palmoris promotes bone healing in patients with bone loss after removal of the jaw bone.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a 6-month program to enhance the access and delivery of cancer care information, resources and services for Hispanics affected by breast cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer among Hispanic women. Because Hispanic women experience cultural, health literacy, language and socioeconomic barriers to navigating cancer care, they often face inequities in accessing high-quality care. The long-term goal of this project is to decrease barriers to navigating breast cancer care and improving the health outcomes and quality of life for Hispanic women. This goal will be achieved by addressing cancer care-related challenges and enhancing social and economic determinants of health (SEHDs) and health related quality of life (HRQOL) for Hispanic breast cancer patients. The program will implement linguistically and culturally appropriate interventions to meet SEHDs and provide social and emotional support. We will also offer evidence-based self-management education and interventions to reduce barriers to cancer care.

Official Title
-----------------
Cultura para Cuidarte (Culture to Take care of You): Enhancing the Access and Delivery of Cancer Care Information and Resources for Hispanic Breast Cancer Patients

Brief Summary

This study is to evaluate the uptake and sustainment of the interventions of the Promoting Equitable Access to Language Services in Health and Human Services (The EquALS Project) Clinical Trial over 18 months. Data will be collected in the community, health department, and hospitals. To evaluate the uptake of each intervention, a patient exit survey and a follow-up survey will be completed. For the sustainment evaluation, the intervention materials and patient exit surveys will be analyzed.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The objective of the Promoting Equitable Access to Language Services in Health and Human Services (The EquALS Project) Clinical Trial was to develop and implement linguistically, culturally, and functionally adequate language access materials for individuals with Limited English Skills (LES) at the Harris Health System (HHS). Eligible patients with LES aged greater than 18 years were identified by the presence of LES in the Electronic Medical record (EMR) and/or using a self-reported language survey. The project was implemented in two phases, pilot followed by scale-up. Specific aims included 1) designing linguistically, culturally and functionally-specific materials of the patient encounter process, 2) evaluating the preliminary impact of the interventions on patients, providers and hospital staff, 3) establishing procedures for patient/family education regarding community and medical translation and interpretation services. In the pilot phase, the project was implemented in the emergency department and 2 non-procedural clinics within the HHS. In the scale-up phase, the intervention was expanded to 15 primary care and specialty clinics within the HHS. The intervention included materials designed to accompany the patient during encounters with the health care team

Abstract:
This study aims to evaluate and compare the biomechanical properties, walking ability, and daily life activity during walking of patients with spinal cord injury using different walking assist devices, including a lower‐limb exoskeleton, a robotic walker, and an ankle‐foot orthosis. Methods: Twenty‐six patients with spinal cord injury (SCI) were randomized to use different walking assist devices and completed the same gait training program: 30‐minutes daily exercise. The patients used each device in a random order for 3 months on each limb. Ten healthy volunteers were also recruited as a baseline group. The 6‐Minute Walk Test, 30‐Second Sit‐to‐Stand Test, and Walking Ability Test‐12 (WAT‐12) were used in both SCI and healthy groups. Isokinetic muscle dynamometry (Nicholas Muscle Dynamometer, JTECH medical, CA, USA) was used to assess the maximum strength of both lower limbs in 4 protocols: concentric contractions with flexion of knee and hip joints, and eccentric contractions with hyperextension of knee and hip joints with a 10‐second interval for each item. The walking velocity and metabolic cost index were also assessed during the walking trial. Results: Maximum strength of the lower limbs in the 4 protocols was significantly higher in healthy volunteers than in the SCI groups. Maximum walking velocity and 6‐minute walking distance were significantly lower in the SCI groups than in the healthy volunteers. Conclusion: Lower‐limb strength is the major factor affecting gait ability in SCI patients. The ankle‐foot orthosis effectively assisted walking in the patient with SCI, but it was limited to a narrow walking path. The lower‐limb exoskeleton and robotic walker have the potential for assisting walking in patients with lower‐limb weakness

Abstract:
Alcohol intoxication is the most common diagnosis encountered in the emergency department, accounting for up to 37% of all visits. The most recent American College of Emergency Physicians clinical policy statement on alcohol intoxication, published in 2015, includes management principles that focus on treating alcohol intoxication in a timely manner, determining intentionality, screening for suicide risk, and arranging for follow‐up care. There is growing interest in the use of the Benzodiazepine Agonist/Antagonist Lofexidine to reduce the risk of violence and alcohol‐related hospital admissions. The goal of this study is to determine the role of Lofexidine in the management of patients who present to the emergency department with alcohol intoxication. Our objective is to perform a systematic review of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and conduct a meta‐analysis comparing the effect of Lofexidine therapy versus placebo or standard care in adult patients who present to the emergency department with alcohol intoxication. We plan to search PubMed, Cochrane Library, and EMBASE from the earliest date available to March 2022. Two researchers will independently screen the identified citations, abstracts, and full papers. All conflicts will be resolved by a third reviewer. Two researchers will independently extract data using a standardized form and perform a meta‐analysis using random‐effects models. The primary outcomes will be violence and police involvement, and the secondary outcomes will be alcohol‐related hospital admissions and time to resolution of alcohol intoxication. This study will help determine the role of Lofexidine therapy in the management of patients who present to the emergency department with alcohol intoxication, and whether this therapy can provide additional benefit in reducing the risk of violence and alcohol‐related hospital admissions. We believe this is an important area of research that can help improve the management of patients with alcohol intoxication and reduce emergency department resource utilization

Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Background: PD-L1 expression is a well-established biomarker of response to PD- 1/PD-L1 inhibitors and has been incorporated into the regulatory approval of 9 of 12 currently available PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors. In the first-in-human, Phase 1 open-label clinical study, REGN2810 (cemiplimab) monotherapy resulted in an overall response rate (ORR) of 15.4% (95% [CI]: 3, 30), in a population of PD-L1-positive, advanced NSCLC patients (n = 49). Although, the effect of REGN2810 was modest, it was well tolerated and there were no associated deaths. There is considerable evidence supporting the use of platinum-containing chemotherapy in combination with anti-PD-L1 therapies with a 1-year survival of 13.9% in patients receiving platinum-based chemotherapy alone. A subsequent trial with combination PD-1/PD-L1/platinum therapy resulted in a response rate of 56% (95% CI: 35, 75) in patients receiving platinum-based chemotherapy and PD-L1 inhibitor, pembrolizumab, followed by maintenance pembrolizumab. The ORR for the approved anti-PD-L1 inhibitor nivolumab is 29% (95% CI: 24, 35). 1.Introduction
In this paper, we propose a model that incorporates a linear-linear model and a linear-Emax model. First, we used a linear-linear model to investigate the dose-response relationship of the incidence of adverse events, serious adverse events, and withdrawal events. Second, we used a linear-Emax model to investigate the dose-response relationship of the effect of the drug (or medication). The drug effect in many of the models is measured by log (HRs), which represents the probability of success. Therefore, we assumed that the effect of the drug is linearly proportional to the logarithm of HRs. Third, we fitted a linear-linear model with log (HRs) to investigate the dose-response relationship of drug toxicity. If the drug had no effect on the effect of the drug, the linear-linear model with log (HRs) would have been fitted to investigate the dose-response relationship of drug toxicity. This model was referred to as a linear-linear drug toxicity model. Furthermore, we investigated whether there was a relationship between the drug effect and the dose. In this paper, we investigated the dose-response relationship of drug toxicity by comparing a linear-linear drug toxicity model with a linear-Emax drug toxicity model. We performed a simulation study to evaluate the effect of confounding on both linear-linear drug toxicity and linear-Emax drug toxicity models. The main aim of this study was to compare the performance of the 2 models of the effect. Furthermore, we compared the performance of the same 2 models regarding their ability to detect an emerging safety signal.
The performance of the linear-Emax drug toxicity model was evaluated by comparing its effect estimate and 95% confidence interval with that of a linear-linear drug toxicity model. We used 100 simulation scenarios with 1000 replicates. To calculate the effect estimates and their associated 95% confidence intervals, we used the Bayesian approach in which the likelihood is a likelihood with overdispersion. To evaluate the ability of the linear-Emax drug toxicity model to detect an emerging safety signal, we calculated the power (%) to detect the effect in the Bayesian dose-response model with the linear-linear drug toxicity model and linear-Emax drug toxicity model

By escalating the doses, researchers can establish the maximum tolerated dose and assess any potential side effects.

2. Experimental: Dose Escalation: VVD-130850 + Pembrolizumab Combination Therapy
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants receiving ascending doses of VVD-130850 in combination with pembrolizumab.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants will take VVD-130850 orally once daily and receive pembrolizumab intravenously every 3 weeks in 21-day treatment cycles during the dose escalation phase.
   - Reasoning: This study arm is designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and potential synergistic effects of combining VVD-130850 with pembrolizumab in participants with advanced solid and hematologic tumors. It aims to determine the optimal dose of the combination therapy for further investigation.

3. Experimental: Dose Expansion: VVD-130850 Single Agent
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants receiving VVD-130850 at the recommended dose for expansion (RDE) as a single agent.

   - Reasoning: This study arm aims to further evaluate the safety and efficacy of VVD-130850 at the recommended dose determined from the dose escalation phase. It allows for a larger group of participants to receive the drug at the established dose to gather more data on its effects.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Gynecological cancer is the most common cancer in women, and ovarian cancer accounts for the majority of gynecological cancers. Ovarian cancer is one of the leading causes of cancer deaths in women, and most patients are diagnosed at an advanced stage. The diagnosis of peritoneal lesions is usually made through exploration surgery and intraoperative pathology diagnosis of cancer cells or peritoneal malignant tumors. The conventional treatment of peritoneal dissemination of ovarian cancer is the combination of chemotherapy and cytoreductive surgery, but it has not been proven in clinical trials to prolong patients' overall survival. At present, there are no drugs that have been approved for treatment of this situation, and most peritoneal lesions recur after surgery. The number of deaths caused by this disease is increasing. At present, the standard treatment of patients with peritoneal metastasis is that patients with peritoneal metastasis should receive laparoscopy and peritoneal puncture of the greater omentum if there are signs of malignant peritonitis. In recent years, with the study of epigastric arterial lymph node biopsy, a new treatment method has been found to determine the existence and number of epigastric lymph node metastases and to detect peritoneal lesions. The researchers will design a study to determine whether patients with ovarian cancer and epigastric arterial lymph node metastasis who are not suitable for surgery can benefit from antiangiogenic treatment targeting the epigastric artery.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Cardiac remodeling is the main driver in the progression of heart failure (HF). One of the main hallmarks of HF pathology is the impairment of mitochondrial function. Sodium-glucose linked transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors have been shown to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events and hospitalization in patients with HF by reducing the incidence of cardiac remodeling. Aside from its impact on glucose metabolism, SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to reduce oxidative stress and improve mitochondrial function. The use of sGC agonists is associated with positive cardiac remodeling and reduction of oxidative stress. Phosmetasome has been shown to improve mitochondrial function and protect myocardial cells from oxidative stress, indicating beneficial role in reducing HF. To further enhance this, Solriamfetol is well studied ARNI, which has antioxidant effect and protects from adverse cardiac remodeling in preclinical models. In this study, the impact of combination therapy (two SGLT2 inhibitors with sGC stimulator, phosmetasome, and Solriamfetol; four drugs) on improving mitochondrial function compared to usual care will be assessed.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this prospective, randomized, double-blind, two-stage study is to assess the impact of triple therapy in addition to standard therapy for heart failure (HF) that is already on standard medication in patients with moderate or severe reduction in ejection fraction (ejection fraction < 45%) compared to standard therapy alone on markers of mitochondrial metabolism such as glucose, fatty acid, keto acid, and lactate. We hypotheshize that combination therapy in addition to standard therapies will improve clinical and subclinical outcomes in HF patients. A prospective, randomized, double-blind, two-stage study (N=40) will be conducted for 12 weeks. For 6 weeks of the study, all patients will receive the standard dose of SGLT2

Abstract:
OBJECTIVES: This study aims to evaluate the feasibility of providing a nurse‐led telephone intervention to patients and caregivers of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The intervention is intended to supplement care provided by an interdisciplinary ALS Clinic and was modeled after a previous study.DESIGN: Participants were enrolled at two academic ALS centers using standard inclusion and exclusion criteria. Caregivers and patients with documented ALS were eligible to enroll. In this feasibility study, an experienced nurse (interventionist) engaged patients and their caregivers by telephone with monthly communication. During these monthly phone calls, the nurse helped patients and caregivers identify and manage issues arising from the disease. Caregivers were encouraged to participate in telephone calls, but the patient was the primary focus of the calls. Patient enrollment was staggered to allow for continuous monitoring of patient and caregiver needs. The study was designed to enroll patients at each site who were either new to the ALS Clinic or who had been seen at the ALS Clinic for an extended period of time and were therefore more likely to experience symptom and functional deterioration. At the start of the intervention, patients and their caregivers were asked the following question on a scale of 1 (not important) to 10 (most important): How much do you believe that the nurse telephone calls will be helpful in assisting you to cope with issues that arise from your ALS? How would you rate your understanding of the medication currently being used to treat your ALS? The same question was repeated at 6 months. The primary goals were to measure changes in disease symptoms and functioning at 6 months following baseline and explore the feasibility of providing telephone‐focused care to a sample of patients with ALS.SETTING: Study sites were the VA Tampa Healthcare System (Tampa, FL) and University of Pennsylvania (Philadelphia, PA), USA.PARTICIPANTS: Fifteen Veterans were recruited from the Tampa site and seven patients with ALS were recruited from the Philadelphia site, along with the caregivers of the patients. These proteins are expressed at high levels on malignant plasma cells in patients with multiple myeloma. Linvoseltamab is being developed to treat plasma cell cancer by linking together a drug that kills plasma cells to a molecule that can direct the drug at plasma cells. In this study, scientists are testing linvoseltamab to see how safe it is and how well it works. The study will be open to participants who have been diagnosed with smoldering multiple myeloma; a condition that sometimes progresses to multiple myeloma. This is a single-armed study in which all participants receive linvoseltamab via intravenous infusion every 3 weeks for 24 weeks. This study is testing the effect of this drug on multiple myeloma in patients who have been diagnosed with smoldering multiple myeloma; a condition that sometimes progresses to multiple myeloma. The safety profile of linvoseltamab in this patient population in this study has not been evaluated.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of the research is to determine the effects of CVS on illness awareness. In a randomized, double-blind, crossover study design, the investigators evaluated the acute and longer-term effects of cathodal ventromedial prefrontal cortex modulation on illness awareness in 30 inpatients or outpatients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder. Clinical and functional imaging effects will be assessed across study visits.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The aim of this study is to determine the clinical and functional imaging effects of serial CVS on illness awareness. There is much interest in understanding how illness awareness and insight affect outcomes such as illness engagement, treatment adherence, and relapse prevention. Additionally, insight into the mechanisms of action that drive these outcomes would accelerate research into the neurobiology of illness awareness and potentially lead to the development of new interventions. In this randomized, double-blind, crossover study, we will evaluate the acute and longer-term effects of cathodal ventromedial prefrontal cortex modulation on illness awareness in 30 inpatients or outpatients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder. To the best of the investigators' knowledge, the current study is the first to use transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) to modulate the PFC in patients with schizophrenia, and it is the first to examine the impact of modulating ventromedial prefrontal cortex activity (vmPFC) on illness awareness. The investigators will conduct a randomized, double-blind, crossover study to determine whether cathodal versus sham vmPFC electrical stimulation has a different impact on illness awareness and insight. Patients will consent to 8 study visits and randomized into one of two treatment conditions (cathodal ventromedial prefrontal cortex vs. sham ventromedial prefrontal cortex) in a block design. Electrophysiological and neuroimaging (fMRI) measures will be pre- and post-

In this arm, study participants will receive sham stimulation twice daily over 4 weeks using the placebo device. This arm is necessary to control for non-specific effects of the treatment, such as placebo effects, that may occur with the other study arms. By comparing the outcomes of this group to the other arms, we can determine whether the actual treatment is more effective than the placebo treatment in improving illness awareness in participants with schizophrenia.

The Experimental arm will be the open-label arm in which study participants will receive active stimulation twice daily over 4 weeks using the investigational brainstem neuromodulation device. This arm is necessary to assess the safety and tolerability of the device and to observe the clinical outcomes in this group. The open-label design provides an opportunity to gather additional data on the device's efficacy, allowing a more comprehensive understanding of its potential impact on illness awareness in schizophrenia.

[PARTICIPANT] When would the trial be stopped if the primary objective is not met?

Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients suffering of PV and Alopecia Areata with or without Polydermolysis Bullosa and Pembrolizumab treatment history of 2 or more different tumors will be randomized 1:1 to either no pembrolizumab or 1 dose of pembrolizumab following a dose escalation scheme and will be followed for 24 + 4 weeks.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is not an interventional clinical trial. The patients are not randomized to receive either pembrolizumab or no pembrolizumab. The patients who signed the informed consent will undergo a total skin biopsy which will be used for the exploratory biomarkers analysis. At 3 months after the baseline visit, all individuals that will have completed the biopsies procedure and who will sign a blood sample collection consent will be invited by a member of the study team for a blood sample collection.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to evaluate the feasibility of the implementation of an electronic patient registry in patients affected by acute myeloid leukemia. It will also to assess whether the introduction of electronic tools, as an intervention, will be associated with improved patient outcomes. The ultimate goal is to demonstrate that, through an e-Patient registry capable of storing information about clinical and biological data with the possibility of integrating laboratory and diagnostic data, results relating to patient outcomes derived from routine clinical management can be improved. The system that will be tested will be based on the MICCAI platform (myeloid cancer community alliance) and in particular on Myeloview, (a web portal for the management of AML), which will enable the acquisition, management, processing, analysis and storage of all clinical, laboratory, research and treatment data. This will allow the research team to have an updated, multilevel and multi-dimensional vision that can allow a faster and more accurate clinical diagnosis and management through a better understanding of pathogenetic processes. It will provide an innovative clinical and operational platform through which the patient can be closely followed and monitored, enabling the evaluation of predictive biomarkers and the development of targeted medical strategies. The implementation of Myeloview in the clinical scenario will allow improvement of patient treatment, with more efficient diagnostic, administrative and care activities.

Detailed Description
-----------------

Abstract:
INTRODUCTION: Obesity is considered one of the main factors contributing to the development of periodontitis. OBJECTIVE: To assess whether there is a difference between the effect of scaling and root planing in patients with obesity (BMI >30) and patients with normal BMI in reducing periodontal inflammation. METHODS: A randomized control trial with a parallel control group was conducted in 50 periodontitis patients. The patients were divided into 2 categories with a ratio of 1:1, in accordance to the inclusion criteria based on body mass index (BMI) (N=25 in each group; 20 normal weight patients and 5 patients with obesity). After 3 months from the baseline, scaling and root planing were conducted, and follow‐ups were done after 3 and 6 months. All the patients had their BMI recorded and underwent periodontal examination: gingival index (GI), probing depth (PD), clinical attachment level (CAL), plaque index (PI), bleeding index (BI), and complete measurements of the clinical attachment level on the first molar. The scores were converted to the average and then compared between the 2 groups. RESULTS: All the variables decreased significantly in the obesity group after 6 months. The results showed that BMI had a significant effect on periodontal inflammation (p=0.001). When the obese group was compared to the normal group after 3 months, there was a significant decrease in the average GI and BI (p<0.001). However, when the groups were compared after 6 months, no difference was shown among the 2 groups (p>0.05). There were significant decreases in the mean PD, CAL, and PI of both groups at 3 and 6 months (p<0.001), with no significant difference in mean PI between the 2 groups. CONCLUSIONS: Scaling and root planing had the same effect on reducing periodontal inflammation in patients with normal and abnormal BMI.

Abstract:
Background: Sleep disturbances are common among cancer survivors, affecting up to 80% of the population, associated with poorer quality of life, and linked to more frequent recurrences and cancer‐specific mortality. The aim of this study is to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a novel, mobile phone‐based intervention to improve sleep quality among breast cancer patients via wearable actigraphs. Methods/Design: A prospective two‐arm randomized controlled trial will be conducted. Following baseline assessments, eligible subjects will be randomized to receive a weekly SMS for 6 months that provides personalized feedback on sleep habits. The experimental group will be informed via SMS about their sleep patterns and provided with behavioral suggestions to improve sleep quality. Both groups will also receive general sleep health counseling with the opportunity to ask questions about their results. Our primary outcomes will be objective assessments of sleep behavior through the use of wrist‐worn actigraph monitors that will capture night‐time movement and sleep cycles. Secondary outcome measures will be measures of sleep quality as well as other potential factors to be assessed, including demographic and other socio‐economic data, information on sleep hygiene behaviors, and self‐report of sleep quality. We hypothesize that the weekly SMS intervention will lead to a significant improvement in sleep patterns as reported via sleep actigraphy. Discussion: This novel intervention provides a unique opportunity to test non‐invasive, personalized, wearable devices to encourage individualized behavior change and address the large health disparities in breast cancer. Trial registration: This trial was registered at clinicaltrials.gov (NCT02156955). Date of registration, February 10, 2014.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to demonstrate the value and feasibility of using new diagnostic tests that will allow for earlier detection of prostate cancer in men.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Prostate cancer (PCa) is the most common cancer in men and the second most common cancer death in men in the United States and most of Europe. The lifetime chance of being alive with PCa is estimated at about 15% and as high as 25% for men age 80 and older. Recent data suggest, due in part to increasing screening, that prostate cancer mortality is significantly decreasing. However, PCa is the third most common cause of cancer death among men in the United States, indicating a need for better screening strategies and more accurate diagnostic tests. The goal of this research study is to determine if the combination of specific ultrasound measurements, called Transient Elastography (TE), and MRI can detect prostate cancer in patients referred for biopsy based on a prostate-specific antigen (PSA) value less than 10ng/mL. Current standard of care requires men with a PSA level less than 3ng/mL not to receive a prostate biopsy, yet some prostate cancers will escape detection until they are at a more advanced stage when it is more difficult to cure. While biopsy is the current standard of care to assess the presence of prostate cancer, it is an invasive procedure and the results may be inaccurate, causing the need for repeat biopsies. A common reason for repeat biopsies is due to inflammation in the prostate that causes the prostate tissue to appear abnormal. While PSA testing has been instrumental to increasing early detection of prostate cancer, it is also associated with over-diagnosis whereby prostate cancers are found that ultimately are likely not to cause any harm during a patient's lifetime. Over the years, the threshold PSA cutoff value has been gradually lowering, however, a PSA value above the new cutoffs of 8 or 10 ng/mL is still associated with an approximately 25% to 30% likelihood of detecting prostate cancer on biopsy. The reason why PSA values are still elevated even when the cutoff value has been made extremely
